intro: Astragalus arnoldi f. albiflorus, commonly known as the white-flowered milkvetch, is a rare and distinctive plant species belonging to the legume family, Fabaceae. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and its unique feature of producing white flowers, which set it apart from other members of the Astragalus genus. This subspecies is native to specific regions in North America, particularly in the western United States, where it thrives in dry, rocky habitats. The plant is notable for its small, pod-like fruits that contain seeds adapted for dispersal by wind. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Astragalus arnoldi f. albiflorus is considered a valuable subject for botanical research and conservation efforts.
